abstract.p: Dr Antonia Martinez letter comments on June 27 articles on decoding of human genome, saying it is absurd for anyone to claim a patent of any part of human genome; drawing

block.p: Perhaps I should send my parents to the patent office to stake a claim on my genetic code (human genome coverage, June 27). Would that allow me to circumvent someone's new patent on a gene sequence that Mom and Dad and their forefathers ''invented'' decades ago? Centuries ago? It seems absurd for anyone to claim a patent of any part of the human genome. That type of exploitation is a recipe for disaster.

Perhaps I should send my parents to the patent office to stake a claim on my genetic code (human genome coverage, June 27). Would that allow me to circumvent someone's new patent on a gene sequence that Mom and Dad and their forefathers ''invented'' decades ago? Centuries ago? It seems absurd for anyone to claim a patent of any part of the human genome. That type of exploitation is a recipe for disaster.
What makes more sense is granting patents for the invention of new genetic programming. Let's see a new sequence that ''turns off'' the cancer gene or overrides male pattern baldness.
While I have nothing against scientists and bio-preneurs profiting from their discoveries, patents on the existing human genome are not appropriate rewards.
